Palladium nanoparticles encapsuled in MOF: An efficient dual-functional catalyst to produce benzylmalononitrile derivatives by one-pot reaction Yu-Yang Zhang Writing – original draft Software Investigation Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ Mei-Li Zhou Investigation Validation Formal analysis Visualization Software Data curation Yan-Sai Bao Resources Visualization Ming Yang Resources Visualization Yong-He Cui Resources Visualization Da-Liang Liu Resources Supervision Qiong Wu Resources Supervision Lin Liu Conceptualization Methodology Resources Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Zheng-Bo Han Writing – review & editing College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China College of Chemistry, Liaoning University Shenyang 110036 PR China College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) encapsuled metal nanoparticles (NPs) have great potential in catalysis, while their synergistic catalysis in the one-pot reaction is still a largely untapped area, and reports are very limited. Herein, Pd NPs were loaded on a zeolite-type MOF (MIL-101(Cr)-NH2) via post-synthetic impregnation approach to form composites Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. In addition, the obtained dual-functional Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 showed great catalytic performance (>99% yields) in the one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel and Heck-Knoevenagel reactions. Furthermore, all characterization methods showed that catalyst with Pd-Brønsted base had high stability to avoid metal agglomeration, leaching, and still maintained high activity after 6 cycles under the same circumstances. These reactions had potential significance for the production of benzylmalononitrile derivatives with high economic benefits. Graphical abstract Pd NPs were loaded into a zeolite-type MOF (MIL-101(Cr)-NH2) via post-synthetic impregnation approach to form Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. Satisfactorily, the obtained Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 bearing two active sites has successfully catalyzed one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction and Heck-Knoevenagel reaction by perfect synergistic collaboration between the Brønsted base host and the Pd NPs guest. Furthermore, the dual-functional catalyst had high stability to avoid metal agglomeration, leaching, and still maintained high activity after recovered 6 cycles under the same circumstances. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Palladium nanoparticles One-pot reaction Dual-functional catalyst 1 Introduction Benzylmalononitrile derivatives (BMDs) with unique chemical and biological activities are significant intermediates for the synthesis of pesticides, medicines, dyes, etc. [1–4]. In terms of medicine, the vitamin B1 synthesized by them is necessary for human energy metabolism [5]. For pesticides, a variety of compounds synthesized with BMDs are widely used in weed control, insecticide, and sterilization [6]. As far as dyes are concerned, the BMDs dyes have the advantages of pure color, bright and translucent, and not easy to decolorize [7]. In the past decade, scientists have been committed to developing a comprehensive strategy to prepare BMDs [8]. Although some progress has been made in this regard, it still needs to be improved. Therefore, it is a challenge for us to find a green and energy-saving method to synthesize BMDs. As is well-known, Heck and Sonogashira reactions are highly effective methods to synthesize C=C and CC among all CC coupling reactions [9,10], which are very common reactions in the synthesis of chemical raw materials and drugs [10–13]. Generally speaking, Heck and Sonogashira reactions require the presence of palladium complexes bearing phosphine ligands [14,15]. However, the disadvantage of palladium complexes bearing phosphine ligands is that they are sensitive to oxygen and humidity, and it is expensive to create an inert environment for them [16,17]. Moreover, their toxicity limits industrial applications to a certain extent. Therefore, the production of non-phosphine catalysts with higher activity and stability has attracted widespread interest. As for Knoevenagel condensation, it is a classical reaction to prepare malononitrile derivatives by introducing a nitrile-based active methylene compound and an aldehyde [18]. Overall, it could be catalyzed by catalysts with Lewis or Bronsted base sites [19]. To produce BMDs, it is a good strategy to combine Heck and Sonogashira reaction with Knoevenagel condensation [15,20,21]. But multistep reactions of Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction and Heck-Knoevenagel reaction are not only time-consuming, but also need complex purification process. Therefore, it is urgent to obtain BMDs with high yield in one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel and Heck-Knoevenagel reactions over a multifunctional catalyst, which reduces energy consumption and simplifies the synthesis process. In addition, the one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction and Heck-Knoevenagel reaction had not been reported so far. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) consist of clusters or metal ions and organic ligands through coordination bond [22], and have unique properties, such as controllable pore size and modified pore surface, low density, high surface area [23,24], which makes the new porous material has widely used in many fields, for example, adsorption [25,26], photocatalysis [27,28] and catalysis [29,30] et al. In particular, MOFs can be used as a substitute for zeolite because their specific surface area and pore size can be adjusted in a wider range [31–33]. Furthermore, the high crystallinity of MOFs, coupled with the molecular level design of the structures, contribute to stronger catalytic selectivity [22,34–36]. In addition, the size-adjustable cage structure or channel in MOFs enable them to accommodate or support guest materials to form MOFs composites, such as metal NPs@MOFs [37], carbon nanostructures@MOFs [38], polyoxometalates@MOFs [18], ionic liquids@MOFs [39] and enzyme@MOFs [40]. Especially, for metal NPs@MOFs, MOFs with porous structure could efficiently avoid aggregation of metal NPs, and the highest catalytic performance could be achieved on the metal NPs@MOFs systems, where the nodal metal ions and aromatic backbone of MOFs could strongly interact with loaded metal NPs through coordination and π–π forces [41]. In the past few years, there have been preliminarily explored the synthesis and application of metal NPs@MOFs [42–44]. However, the metal NPs@MOFs composite designed for dual-functional co-catalysis is still a largely undeveloped area, and reports are very limited. Therefore, there is still a long way to further explore dual-functional metal NPs@MOFs composites in the future. Compared with several common MOFs, such as UiO-66 [45–48], HKUST-1 [49], etc., MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 is one of the most famous MOFs due to its high thermal and chemical stability and its large apparent surface area [50]. Thus, in this work, a dual-functional composite was constructed by loading Pd NPs on a zeolite-type MOF (MIL-101(Cr)-NH2) via post-synthetic impregnation approach. Satisfactorily, the obtained Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 bearing two active sites has successfully catalyzed one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction and Heck-Knoevenagel reaction by perfect synergistic collaboration between the Brønsted base host and the Pd NPs guest. As for catalyzing Sonogashira and Heck reactions, there is no need to add phosphorus complexes and additional bases, which is consistent with the concept of green, environmental protection and safety. Moreover, this is the first time to produce BMDs with high economic benefits through one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction and Heck-Knoevenagel reaction by applying Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 as catalyst, and laid a firm foundation for the production of medicines, pesticides and dyes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Characterization Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 were carried out on the Nicolet 5DX spectrometer by applying KBr particles. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were recorded with a PerkinElmer Pyrisl instrument (25∼800 °C, 5 °C min−1, flowing N2). The power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker AXS D8 advanced automated diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was recorded on a JEOL-2010 electron microscope with an electron acceleration energy of 200 kV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were gained on a Hitachi SU8010 system (Japan) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an ESCALAB 250Xi system equipped with Al Kα radiation. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BET surface area was detected by a 3H-2000PS1 analyzer (Beishide Instrument Co, China). The contents of Pd NPs in Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 were determined quantitatively by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, Optima 2000DV). The yield of catalytic reaction product was analyzed and identified by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Agilent 5975C). Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was carried out applying a BEL CATA II instrument. Firstly, 80 mg of sample was pretreated at 120 °C under He flowing for 1 h, and cooled to 50 °C. Then, CO2 (30∼50 mL min−1) gas was introduced and maintained for 1 h, and purged with He gas to remove the physically adsorbed CO2. Finally, the desorption tests were performed at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 (50∼400°C), while mass spectrometry (MS) analysis was performed to monitor desorbed species. 2.2 Materials 2.2.1 Chemicals All chemicals for synthesis were commercially available reagents of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Cr(NO3)3•9H2O, ZrCl4, Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, PdCl2, 2-aminoterephthalic acid (H2BDCNH2), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, 4-halogenated phenyl aldehyde, olefin, alkyne, NaBH4, malononitrile, NaOH were all purchased from Aladdin and used directly. DMF, ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, DMA, 1,4-dioxane, toluene, THF, DMSO were analytical grade. N2 (99.999%) gases were gained from Shenyang Shengfeng high pressure gas Co., Ltd (China). 2.2.2 Preparation of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 The MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was a slightly improved synthesis based on the approach of previous report [52]. Typically, Cr(NO3)3•9H2O (1.20 g, 3.00 mmol), H2BDCNH2 (0.54 g, 3 mmol) and NaOH (0.24 g, 6.00 mmol) were mixed in the presence of 30 mL ultrapure water and sonicated, stirred for 1 h at room temperature, then heated at 423 K for 12 h. NaOH were dissolved in the mixture to provide an alkaline environment, which can increase the crystallinity of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. The obtained dark-green MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 crystals were filtrated and washed several times with DMF, methanol and dichloromethane, finally heated 12 h at 353 K under vacuum for further use. 2.2.3 Preparation of Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 At room temperature, 80 μL, 120 μL, 160 μL, and 200 μL Na2PdCl4 methanol solution (0.125 mol/L, 1 mmol) was added into MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 (50 mg) under intense stirring of 0.5 h, respectively. MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 infiltrated with Pd2+ was washed three times with methanol. Then, 3 mL of a 0.6 mol/L NaBH4 methanol solution was added dropwise while the mixture was being stirred until the color of the solution became dark and washed with methanol for 5 times, finally the 0.5∼2.0 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 were obtained. After the MOF powders were separated by centrifugation and heated at 423 K for 12 h under vacuum for further use. Among them, Pd contents of x wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 were analyzed by ICP-AES. 2.3 Catalytic tests of one-pot reaction 2.3.1 Catalytic tests of one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction In a 10 mL three-necked reaction reactor, the one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction was catalyzed by magnetic agitation with phenylacetylene (1.0 mmol), 4-iodobenzaldehyde (1.0 mmol) and malononitrile (1.0 mmol) in ethanol (4.0 mL). Then added 20 mg catalyst and kept the reaction at temperature of 343 K. The yields of products were monitored by GC–MS. When the process completed, the catalyst was filtered and separated, fully washed with methanol then vacuumed for reuse in the cyclic reaction. 2.3.2 Catalytic tests of one-pot Heck-Knoevenagel reaction In a 10 mL three-necked reaction reactor, the one-pot Heck-Knoevenagel reaction was catalyzed by magnetic agitation with styrene (1.0 mmol), 4-iodobenzaldehyde (1.0 mmol), malononitrile (1.0 mmol), 4 mL DMF and 20 mg catalyst, the reaction temperature was controlled at 393 K. The yields of products were monitored by GC–MS. When the process completed, the catalyst was filtered and separated, fully washed with methanol then vacuumed for reuse in the cyclic reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The Pd contents doped on MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 could be effectively adjusted by changing the addition amount of Na2PdCl4. Therefore, Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 with different Pd contents in the range of 0.5∼2.0 wt% were obtained. The powder XRD was used to observe whether Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 still preserved their crystal structure and the results were showed in Fig. 1 a. Since all the main peaks of the experimental and simulated PXRD matched well, the phase purity of the framework was good, which confirmed that the MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 loaded with Pd NPs maintained the structure and crystal form of the parent MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. Besides, no related diffraction peaks of Pd NPs were found, indicating that Pd loadings were too low or Pd NPs were too small in all samples, which was similar to previously reported results [53], and it was also consistent with the FT-IR results as the infrared characteristic peaks of 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 could match well with MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 (Fig. 1b). The above-mentioned showed that the frameworks of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 remained integral after loading Pd NPs. Moreover, for the TGA results (Fig. S2), it could be noted that 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was similar to the parent MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 with high thermal stability below 400 °C, indicating that the thermal stability of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was not reduced after loading Pd NPs. Thus, we concluded that 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 with great thermal stability could be one of the important factors as high activity catalyst. There are two main parameters to evaluate the catalytic capacity of porous materials, one is the specific surface area, the other is the pore volume. Fig. 1c and d showed the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 before and after encapsulating Pd NPs, and their physical structure properties were listed in Table 1 . Evidently, all samples were type I isotherms, indicating that they were microporous materials. Contrast to the parent MIL-101(Cr)-NH2, the BET surface area decreased with the loading of Pd NPs, primarily due to the evenly dispersed Pd NPs occupying cavities of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. Besides, the pore size distribution curve measured by DFT method (Fig. 1d) showed that the loading amount of Pd NPs had little effect on the pore size. The morphology and structure of materials were generally studied by electron microscope. The TEM images in Fig. 2 a∼d revealed that Pd NPs have been homogeneously dispersed into MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 and no apparent formation of aggregations were surveyed. And it should be noted that when the loading amount of Pd was 2.0 wt%, there was a slight agglomeration of Pd NPs. As shown in Fig. 2e∼f, 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 had a uniform size of 1.4 ± 0.4 nm, which was very consistent with the cavity size (2.9–3.4 nm) in MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. These results indicated that large pore size of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was conducive to the diffusion of metal precursor Na2PdCl4 and the deposition of small Pd NPs. HRTEM images showed that the face spacing of a selected representative particle lattice of large-size Pd NPs was 0.224 nm, which belonged to the (111) lattice spacing of facial cubic Pd (Fig. 2c). The surface morphologies of MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 before and after encapsulating 1.5 wt% Pd NPs samples were shown in Fig. S1a∼b, as the parent MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 crystals were small in size, regular in dispersion, and after loading Pd NPs, 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 maintained the morphology of the parent MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. In addition, as EDX images shown in Fig. S1c, C, Cr, O, N and Pd elements were observed to be evenly distributed, indicating dual-functional Pd@MOF was successfully constructed. Moreover, the contents of loaded Pd NPs (1.52 wt%) were also confirmed by ICP-AES, which was consistent with the content of the Pd in EDX results. To further study the surface element composition and electronic states of the catalyst, we performed XPS analysis on 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. The survey spectrum indicated it was constituted of C, Cr, O, N and Pd elements (Fig. 3 a). As shown in Fig. 3b, the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks of Pd(0) were 335.34 and 340.59 eV, respectively. The 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks of Pd2+ were 337.27 and 342.39 eV, respectively [54,55]. According to the analysis data, Pd in 1.5 wt%Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 mainly existed in reduced state Pd(0). The N 1 s spectrum was deconvoluted into two different components, which were assigned to NC and NH bonds respectively (Fig. 3c) [38,56]. For C 1 s, the spectrum could be decomposed into three peaks, corresponding to CC and OC=O groups in H2BDCNH2 as well as the CN in amine, respectively (Fig. 3d). As for O 1 s spectrum, the peak at 530.67 eV could be attributed to lattice oxygen due to Cr-O bond, and the peak at 532.09 eV might be assigned to surface chemisorption oxygen. In addition, the peak at 531.31 eV could be contributed to the oxygen component of carboxylic acid group [57] (Fig. 3e). And Fig. 3f showed the spectrum of Cr 2p, the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks of Cr3+ were 576.75 and 586.31 eV, respectively. Above results clearly indicated that Pd NPs were perfectly loaded on MIL-101(Cr)-NH2, in which Pd providing metal sites were in the reduced state and -NH2 providing basic sites. The number of basic sites in 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 had great important influence on the catalytic performance of Knoevenagel condensation. Thus, CO2-TPD was used as probe gas to study the number of basic sites in synthetic materials. Fig. 4 a showed the CO2-TPD profiles of MIL-101(Cr), MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 and 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. Obviously, for MIL-101(Cr), there was a peak at 255∼260°C, which might be attributed to CO2 physical adsorption. And there were two different peaks were observed at around 220∼250 °C and 345∼355 °C for MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 and 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2, corresponding to basic sites with different intensities. The peak near 220∼250°C was designated as CO2 molecular adsorption on basic sites with medium intensity, which may be attributed to CO2 physical adsorption or molecular state adsorption sites, probably due to the coupling effect of CO2 and HO groups in MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 and 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 to form HCO3 ∙∙∙Cr. Generally speaking, the desorption temperature of these adsorption sites was relatively low. While the peaks at 345∼355 °C could be due to the chemical adsorption of -NH2 on CO2 to form NH and represented stronger basic sites (Fig. 4a). Moreover, it could be seen that the strong basic sites were slightly weakened with the loading of Pd NPs, which might be due to the influence of Pd NPs on the adsorption of -NH2 on CO2. And the released gas molecules were monitored by mass spectrometry (MS). Fig. 4b showed mass signals during the CO2-TPD-MS measurements over the 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 . 3.2 Catalytic activity studies for one-pot reaction 3.2.1 Catalytic activity of the Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 for catalyzing one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction To prove Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 can be applied as dual-functional catalyst, one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction was chosen for the synthesis of BMDs. As shown in Table 2 , in order to explore the performance of the catalyst and identify the optimal conditions on the reaction, we discussed the effects of reaction temperature, solvent type and contents of Pd loading on one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction, and used MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 as a comparison. Primarily, we explored the effect of temperature on the reaction and found the product yield increased as temperatures increased from 313 to 343 K (Table 2, entries 1∼4), showing that 343 K was the best reaction temperature. The effect of non-polar solvent (1,4-dioxane, toluene), polar aprotic (acetonitrile, DMF, DMA) and protic (ethanol) solvents was investigated as shown in Table 2. For non-polar solvent, lower yield of the product was obtained, but 1,4-dioxane performed better than toluene (Table 2, entries 7∼8). Although the polar aprotic solvents, acetonitrile, DMF proved better than non-polar solvents, but the obtained yield was still not the highest (Table 2, entries 4∼6). Nevertheless, among all solvents, polar protic solvent with ethanol had the highest yield, which may be related to the protonation effect of ethanol (Table 2, entry 9), meanwhile it was cheap and environmentally friendly. For 0.50 to 2.0 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 (Table 2, entries 9∼12), the yields of target product (2- [ [4-(2-Phenylethynyl)-phenyl]methylene]propanedinitrile) were generally excellent (67.1–99.9%). Among them, when the Pd loading was 1.5 wt%, the product yield was as high as 99.9% (Table 2, entry 9), which showed that the optimal Pd loading was 1.5 wt%. For 0.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2, the unsatisfactory yield may be caused by the low Pd contents. As for 2.0 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2, the slight decrease in production may be attributed to blockage of pore channels by over loading Pd, thereby affecting the reaction rate, which was consistent with the TEM results. Therefore, 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 provided a satisfactory yield and was the best catalyst for this reaction. Under the similar reaction condition, when 1.5 wt% Pd@UiO-66(Zr)-NH2 was used as catalyst, the conversion and yield were relatively low, as for 1.5 wt% Pd@HKUST-1 and Pd/C, only Sonogashira reaction occurred, and the yield of the final product was not detected (Table 2, entries 13∼15). Furthermore, when Pd NPs or Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was absent, almost no catalytic reaction occurred (Table 2, entries 16∼17). With the optimized conditions in hand, 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was applied to catalyze a series of one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction of different reactant substrates (Table 3 ). First of all, we investigated the reaction of different alkynes with 4-iodobenzaldehyde and malononitrile. The results showed that when -R was -pH, −4-pHCH3, -n-C4H9, -n-C3H7, −4-pHNO2, −4-pH–OCH3 and −3-pHCl, the yields of product were 78.3∼99.9% (Table 3, entries 1∼7), which indicated that electron-withdrawing group exhibited higher reactivity than electron-donating group. It demonstrated that 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was suitable for this reaction. Then, the reaction of different 4-halophenyl aldehydes with phenylacetylene and malononitrile were also explored. The results showed that when -X was -I, -Br or -Cl, the yield was 99.9, 83.5 and 44.0% (Table 3, entries 1, 8∼9), respectively. This is because iodine atom had less ability to obtain electrons than bromine and chlorine atoms, so that it could better react with alkynes and malononitrile. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity of the Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 for catalyzing one-pot Heck-Knoevenagel reaction Because the results of Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 catalyzed one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction were excellent, we also studied its catalytic performance for preparation of BMDs in one-pot Heck-Knoevenagel reaction. In order to optimize the one-pot Heck-Knoevenagel reaction conditions, styrene, malononitrile and 4-iodobenzaldehyde were used as model substrates, and detailed reaction optimization studies were provided in Table 4 . To confirm effect of temperature on the reaction, the reactions were performed at different temperatures. When temperature was increased from 353 to 413 K, yields of products gradually increased until it reached 99.9% at 393 K (Table 4, entries 1∼4). In addition, the influence of different solvents was studied in depth to achieve the best optimal catalyst conditions, which proved that DMF was the best solvent for the reaction compared with acetonitrile, toluene, DMA, DMSO, THF, and 1,4-Dioxane (Table 4, entries 3, 5∼10). The reaction with various Pd loading of Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 (0.5∼2 wt% based on the Pd element) were conducted (Table 4, entries 3, 11∼13). Among them, 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101-NH2 could be used as an excellent catalyst with the highest yield of 99.9% (Table 4, entry 3). Furthermore, as for 1.5 wt% Pd@UiO-66(Zr)-NH2, 1.5 wt% Pd@HKUST-1 and Pd/C, the yields were not ideal (Table 4, entries 14∼16). In addition, when Pd NPs or Pd@MIL-101-NH2 was absent, almost no product was detected (Table 4, entries 17∼18). Under the best reaction conditions explored above, in order to explore the range of the reaction substrate, different olefins and different halogenated aldehyde reactions were used. First of all, various structural olefins reacted with 4-iodobenzaldehyde and malononitrile to produce the desired products. When -R was -pH and 4-pHCH3, the products could be obtained with higher yields (Table 5 , entries 1∼2). But the yield was not ideal as -R was replace with -n-C4H9, -n-C6H13, and −4-pHCOOEt, respectively (Table 5, entries 3∼5). Then, the reaction of different 4-halophenyl aldehydes, with styrene and malononitrile were also explored. The results showed that when -X was -I, -Br or -Cl, the yield was 99.9, 89.9 and 20.2%, respectively (Table 5, entries 1, 8∼9). This was in line with the previously reported results [15,58]. 3.3 A reasonable reaction mechanism for one-pot reaction A reasonable mechanism for the one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel and Heck-Knoevenagel reactions was discussed. As shown in Scheme 1, the first step of the catalytic cycle, aryl halide was added to the compound Pd(0)-MIL-101(Cr)-NH2, then it reacted with the alkyne or olefins. Next, through the reduction and elimination of the Brønsted base, the intermediate product (1) was obtained. When malononitrile was added, protons were obtained from malononitrile through the Brønsted base of the catalyst to form carbanions and it attacked the carbonyl carbon atom of the intermediate product (1) and transferred the negative charge to the oxygen atom to form a CC bond. Finally, oxygen anion acquired protons from the Brønsted base, while the final product (2) was obtained and the original Pd(0)-MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was retained. 3.4 Leaching experiment of one-pot reaction Fig. 5 a showed one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction curves of phenylacetylene, 4-iodobenzaldehyde and malononitrile with 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. To prove that there was no leaching of Pd NPs during the process, the catalyst was filtered out after the reaction lasted for 1 h. When the catalyst was removed, the reaction did not proceed any more. Fig. 5b showed the one-pot Heck-Knoevenagel reaction curve of styrene, 4-iodobenzaldehyde and malononitrile with 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. The yield was the highest when the reaction lasted for 6 h. To prove that there was no leaching of Pd NPs during the process, the catalyst was filtered out after the reaction lasted for 3 h, when the catalyst was removed, the reaction did not proceed any more. It was consistent with the results of ICP-AES analysis that no Pd was observed in the reaction solution. Therefore, MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 was a highly stable carrier that can effectively protect the loaded Pd NPs. 3.5 Reusability and stability test of 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 In the continuous and efficient industrial production, the repeatability and recoverability of the catalyst are the key performance indexes that have to be considered. Thus, the recyclability of the catalyst after one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel and Heck-Knoevenagel reactions were investigated. After the one-pot reaction, the catalyst was filtered and separated, fully washed with dichloromethane and vacuumed for reuse in the next cyclic reaction. It was found from Fig. 6 a∼b that the catalyst had good durability and slightly reduced the catalytic activity after reused for 6 cycles. The TEM images of catalyst 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 before and reused 6 cycles after one-pot Heck-Knoevenagel and Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reactions showed that Pd NPs still maintained good dispersion without obvious agglomeration (Fig. S3a). The PXRD patterns, FT-IR spectra after six cycles showed that Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 maintained the original crystal structure (Fig. S3b,c). And CO2-TPD images of 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 sample before and after 6 cycles showed its strong basic sites were not weakened (Fig. S3d). In addition, the Pd 3d, N 1 s XPS spectra of 1.5 wt% Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 sample before and reused 6 cycles demonstrated that valence of Pd and N elements remained unchanged after the reaction, further proved the high stability of it (Fig. S3e∼f). These results indicated that the synthesized dual-functional catalyst had excellent stability and recyclability. 4 Conclusions In summary, a robust dual-functional composite material was successfully synthesized via post-synthetic impregnation approach, which showed extremely high catalytic capacity with yields of 99% in one-pot reaction of unsaturated hydrocarbons. MOF (MIL-101(Cr)-NH2) with big porous cage and large specific surface area can effectively load Pd NPs, and its rich Brønsted base sites and Pd NPs could be served as the master-customer collaboration active sites for one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel and Heck-Knoevenagel reactions. Furthermore, the dual-functional catalyst Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 had high stability to avoid metal agglomeration, leaching, and still maintained higher activity after 6 cycles under the same conditions, which absolutely proved its huge potential in industrial catalysis. Moreover, this is the first time to produce BMDs with high economic benefits through one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel reaction and Heck-Knoevenagel reaction. In the future, we will focus on developing more bifunctional catalysts to catalyze one-pot reaction. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) encapsuled metal nanoparticles (NPs) have great potential in catalysis, while their synergistic catalysis in the one-pot reaction is still a largely untapped area, and reports are very limited. Herein, Pd NPs were loaded on a zeolite-type MOF (MIL-101(Cr)-NH2) via post-synthetic impregnation approach to form composites Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2. In addition, the obtained dual-functional Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH2 showed great catalytic performance (>99% yields) in the one-pot Sonogashira-Knoevenagel and Heck-Knoevenagel reactions. Furthermore, all characterization methods showed that catalyst with Pd-Brønsted base had high stability to avoid metal agglomeration, leaching, and still maintained high activity after 6 cycles under the same circumstances. These reactions had potential significance for the production of benzylmalononitrile derivatives with high economic benefits.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium nanoparticles encapsuled in MOF: An efficient dual-functional catalyst to produce benzylmalononitrile derivatives by one-pot reaction
